column4: can anyone recommend a graphics card/chipset that has good performance in Ubuntu and doesn't require proprietary drivers for accelerated 3D? (I'm not a hardcore gamer, so to me "good performance" means "Quake 3 runs smoothly")
some of the older ATI cards had decent DRI driver support
define "older". I'm running a Radeon 8500 now and redraws are slow enough to be disruptive
apparently the radeons up to the 9200 were had their secs released to the DRI project.  My original radeon wasn't too bad for a card of the time.  But I've been using a GeForce 4 for a while now
specs == specs
secs == specs, even
in any case Ubuntu doesn't seem to like my card, which supposedly has good 2D support
I was thinking about replacing it, but I guess there aren't really many other options besides R2xx
hmm... Sorry Ex-Cyber, can't help then :(
it seems like a handful of people have "this problem" (i.e. slow redraws) but the actual underlying problem always seems to be different, and proprietary drivers are involved for most of them
so I don't really know where to go from here
cafuego: I think that depends on what you mean by "decent"
I don't need to run Doom 3
cafuego: I don't notice much of a problem with 3D with this card, just 2D
cafuego: huh?
cafuego: I'm not using fglrx, and don't intend to
I want a card with DRI Project drivers, even if that means I don't get to run the latest whiz-bang id engine
which is part of the reason that I haven't swapped this one out for so long
3D performance is not an issue for me with my current card
but apparently there are 2D problems
is it an ideaological issue with binary drivers, or do you have technical issues with them?
both
